cards.title: Frank Auerbach's London / The extraordinary life and loves

item.title: Frank Auerbach's London: the extraordinary life and loves – in pictures
item.trailText: Auerbach’s canvases reveal his unique vision of London’s streets – from Camden Town caught in vibrant reds and greens, to the autumnal yellow light on Primrose Hill – and the friends who have sat for him over the years
item.standFirst:
With their thick, heavy paint, Auerbach’s canvases reveal his unique vision of London’s streets – from the theatre of Camden Town caught in vibrant reds and greens, to the autumnal yellow light on Primrose Hill – and the friends who have sat for him over the years

  • Frank Auerbach: ‘When you paint you have a fantastic time, you meet lots of girls’

cards.title: Björk's stage fashions through the years
cards.rawTitle: Björk's stage fashions through the years

item.title: Björk's stage fashions through the years – in pictures
item.trailText: Björk plays a one-off show at this year’s Manchester international festival – promising, as ever, as much of a high-fashion thrill as a musical one. We evaluate some of her best stage costumes and designer collaborations over the years
item.standFirst:
Björk plays a one-off show at this year’s Manchester international festival – promising, as ever, as much of a high-fashion thrill as a musical one. We evaluate some of her best stage costumes and designer collaborations over the years

• The Guardian is the festival’s media partner

displayImages.caption:
Debut tour, 1993
For Debut, Björk was all about a pared-back, natural look. The cover for the record, shot by Jean-Baptiste Mondino, had her in a grey jumper and minimal makeup. Onstage, that 90s style was played up with bright white layers of sporty fabric that was all very Helmut Lang. Then there was the hair, with those trademark knots. Cue girl fans – and some boys – getting busy with the hairbands. Photograph: Mimi Steinwehe/Famous
displayImages.altText: Björk Debut
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Debut tour, 1993
For Debut, Björk was all about a pared-back, natural look. The cover for the record, shot by Jean-Baptiste Mondino, had her in a grey jumper and minimal makeup. Onstage, that 90s style was played up with bright white layers of sporty fabric that was all very Helmut Lang. Then there was the hair, with those trademark knots. Cue girl fans – and some boys – getting busy with the hairbands.

displayImages.caption:
Vespertine tour, 2001
Alexander McQueen was one of Björk’s longest-running collaborators. He designed the kimono-style dress she wore on the cover of 1997’s Homogenic and directed the video for Alarm Call. He also worked with her on tour costumes – such as this glitzy disco number, made from strips of sequin with a feathered skirt. All the better to dance in. Photograph: Kevin Mazur/WireImage
displayImages.altText: Björk Alexander McQueen
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Vespertine tour, 2001
Alexander McQueen was one of Björk’s longest-running collaborators. He designed the kimono-style dress she wore on the cover of 1997’s Homogenic and directed the video for Alarm Call. He also worked with her on tour costumes – such as this glitzy disco number, made from strips of sequin with a feathered skirt. All the better to dance in.

displayImages.caption:
Athens Olympics, 2004
Never let it be said that Björk doesn’t make an effort. Everyone knows the swan dress at the Oscars, but another highlight of her dressing-as-an-animal oeuvre was her appearance at the Athens Olympic ceremony as a jellyfish. This masterpiece was created in conjunction with Greek-born, London-based designer Sophia Kokosalaki, who is known for her drapery skills. This may have tested even Kokosalaki’s abilities, however – the gown came with multiple folds and curves to replicate the stinger of the sea. Photograph: Michael Steele/Getty
displayImages.altText: Björk Sophia Kokosalaki
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Athens Olympics, 2004
Never let it be said that Björk doesn’t make an effort. Everyone knows the swan dress at the Oscars, but another highlight of her dressing-as-an-animal oeuvre was her appearance at the Athens Olympic ceremony as a jellyfish. This masterpiece was created in conjunction with Greek-born, London-based designer Sophia Kokosalaki, who is known for her drapery skills. This may have tested even Kokosalaki’s abilities, however – the gown came with multiple folds and curves to replicate the stinger of the sea.

displayImages.caption:
Volta tour, 2007
Though she clearly loves avant garde design for its transformative properties, sometimes it’s also just really LOLs. See her looks for the Volta shows which were made by Bernhard Willhelm, the designer responsible for creating crotchless leotards for men. For Björk, he made use of neon wig hair to make a grass skirt and teamed it with a corset-style top with bone pattern. Half Hawaii, half the mean guy out of Karate Kid at Halloween. All good. Photograph: Tim Mosenfelder/Getty
displayImages.altText: Björk Volta tour Bernhard Willhelm
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Volta tour, 2007
Though she clearly loves avant garde design for its transformative properties, sometimes it’s also just really LOLs. See her looks for the Volta shows which were made by Bernhard Willhelm, the designer responsible for creating crotchless leotards for men. For Björk, he made use of neon wig hair to make a grass skirt and teamed it with a corset-style top with bone pattern. Half Hawaii, half the mean guy out of Karate Kid at Halloween. All good.

displayImages.caption:
Stockholm Music & Arts Festival, 2012
Once she has worked with a designer, Björk tends to runs with their aesthetic. Bernhard Willhelm was at it again with the wig hair and crazy glue in 2012. This time, the singer extended the theme to her actual hair, wearing a blue wig that matches her coat perfectly. It’s like The Addams Family’s Cousin It with a dye job from ombre experts Bleach. And if that’s not a good look, we don’t know what is. Photograph: Annika Berglund
displayImages.altText: Björk Stockholm Music & Arts Festival
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Stockholm Music & Arts Festival, 2012
Once she has worked with a designer, Björk tends to runs with their aesthetic. Bernhard Willhelm was at it again with the wig hair and crazy glue in 2012. This time, the singer extended the theme to her actual hair, wearing a blue wig that matches her coat perfectly. It’s like The Addams Family’s Cousin It with a dye job from ombre experts Bleach. And if that’s not a good look, we don’t know what is.

displayImages.caption:
Biophilia live, Paris, 2013
Dutch designer Iris Van Herpen is at the forefront of clothes that we will wear in the future. As such, Björk is always going to be into what she makes. She began working with Van Herpen in 2013, and the designer came up with the goods from the start with this dress, made using her signature 3D printing techniques. The result is Björk-as-space alien from a planet as yet undiscovered, but definitely worth investigating.
displayImages.altText: Björk Biophilia Iris Van Herpen
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Biophilia live, Paris, 2013
Dutch designer Iris Van Herpen is at the forefront of clothes that we will wear in the future. As such, Björk is always going to be into what she makes. She began working with Van Herpen in 2013, and the designer came up with the goods from the start with this dress, made using her signature 3D printing techniques. The result is Björk-as-space alien from a planet as yet undiscovered, but definitely worth investigating.

displayImages.caption:
Vulnicura live debut,
Carnegie Hall, 2015
Van Herpen was at the 3D printer again this year for Björk’s appearance at Carnegie Hall. This time, the mask she made – which turned the singer into a futuristic dandelion-clock deity – was worn with celestial robes, complete with pleats and shimmery fabric. Quite right for a singer who also doubles as a goddess of style. Photograph: Kevin Mazur/Getty
displayImages.altText: Björk Vulnicura Iris Van Herpen
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Vulnicura live debut,
Carnegie Hall, 2015
Van Herpen was at the 3D printer again this year for Björk’s appearance at Carnegie Hall. This time, the mask she made – which turned the singer into a futuristic dandelion-clock deity – was worn with celestial robes, complete with pleats and shimmery fabric. Quite right for a singer who also doubles as a goddess of style.

cards.title: Got any Mendl's? / Inside Wes Anderson's Bar Luce

item.title: Got any Mendl's? Inside Wes Anderson's Bar Luce
item.trailText: Take a look around Wes Anderson’s bar, which The Grand Budapest Hotel director has kitted out with Steve Zissou pinball tables and Anderson-grade green Formica
item.standFirst: Wes Anderson says he’s designed a great cafe in which to write a movie. Get inspired with this tour around Bar Luce in Milan, which The Grand Budapest Hotel director has kitted out with Steve Zissou pinball tables and Anderson-grade green Formica

displayImages.caption: Fondazione Prada, a newly opened art space in Milan Photograph: Giuseppe Cacace/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Fondazione Prada Prada Foundation, a newly opened art space in Milan
displayImages.cleanCaption: Fondazione Prada, a newly opened art space in Milan

displayImages.caption: Bar Luce was designed by Wes Anderson in the style of the old Milanese cafes. Fondazione Prada is located in Largo Isarco, an industrial zone in Milan Photograph: Giuseppe Cacace/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Waiters at Bar Luce, designed by Wes Anderson in the style of the old Milanese cafes and located in Prada’s Foundation arts venue. Foundation is located in Largo Isarco, an industrial zone in Milan
displayImages.cleanCaption: Bar Luce was designed by Wes Anderson in the style of the old Milanese cafes. Fondazione Prada is located in Largo Isarco, an industrial zone in Milan

displayImages.caption: Anderson’s design was inspired by two films from the golden age of Italian cinema: 1951’s Miracolo a Milano and 1960’s Rocco e i Suoi Fratelli Photograph: Giuseppe Cacace/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Anderson’s design was inspired by two films from the Golden Age of Italian Cinema: 1951’s Miracolo a Milano and 1960’s Rocco e i Suoi Fratelli
displayImages.cleanCaption: Anderson’s design was inspired by two films from the golden age of Italian cinema: 1951’s Miracolo a Milano and 1960’s Rocco e i Suoi Fratelli

displayImages.caption: Fondazione Prada is housed in a century-old distillery redesigned by architect studio OMA as a gallery space and serviced by Anderson’s kitsch cafe Photograph: Giuseppe Cacace/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The Fondazione’s new space is housed in a hundred year old distillery redesigned by architect studio OMA as a gallery space and serviced by Anderson’s kitsch cafe
displayImages.cleanCaption: Fondazione Prada is housed in a century-old distillery redesigned by architect studio OMA as a gallery space and serviced by Anderson’s kitsch cafe

displayImages.caption: Castello Cavalcanti, Anderson’s short starring Jason Schwartzman, features the same green Formica tabletops Photograph: Attilio Maranzano/Fondazione Prada Milano
displayImages.altText: Castello Cavalcanti, Anderson’s short starring Jason Schwartzman features the same green formica
displayImages.cleanCaption: Castello Cavalcanti, Anderson’s short starring Jason Schwartzman, features the same green Formica tabletops

displayImages.caption: “While I do think it would make a pretty good movie set, I think it would be an even better place to write a movie,” Anderson says. “I tried to make it a bar I would want to spend my own non-fictional afternoons in.” Photograph: Giuseppe Cacace/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: “While I do think it would make a pretty good movie set, I think it would be an even better place to write a movie,” Anderson says. “I tried to make it a bar I would want to spend my own non-fictional afternoons in.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: “While I do think it would make a pretty good movie set, I think it would be an even better place to write a movie,” Anderson says. “I tried to make it a bar I would want to spend my own non-fictional afternoons in.”

displayImages.caption: Entertainment includes Steve Zissou and Castello Cavalcanti-themed pinball machines Photograph: Giuseppe Cacace/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Entertainment includes Steve Zissou and Castello Cavalcanti-themed pinball machines
displayImages.cleanCaption: Entertainment includes Steve Zissou and Castello Cavalcanti-themed pinball machines

cards.title: Palmyra / A stunning ancient city under threat
cards.rawTitle: A stunning ancient city under threat

item.title: Palmyra: a stunning ancient city under threat from Isis
item.trailText: Islamic State fighters have engaged Syrian government forces in a battle for control of the ancient and highly symbolic city of Palmyra – threatening the destruction of this world heritage site’s priceless architecture and art
item.standFirst: Islamic State fighters have engaged Syrian government forces in a battle for control of the ancient and highly symbolic city of Palmyra – threatening the destruction of this world heritage site’s priceless architecture and art

displayImages.caption:
Hadrian’s Gate, Palmyra
Known as the ‘Venice of the Sands’, the ancient Syrian city of Palmyra – located at the edge of an oasis of date palms and gardens – was a wealthy caravan centre from the 1st to the 3rd centuries CE, sometimes independent and at other times under the control of Rome Photograph: Fernando arias/Getty Images/Flickr RF
displayImages.altText: Hadrian’s Gate, Palmyra
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Hadrian’s Gate, Palmyra
Known as the ‘Venice of the Sands’, the ancient Syrian city of Palmyra – located at the edge of an oasis of date palms and gardens – was a wealthy caravan centre from the 1st to the 3rd centuries CE, sometimes independent and at other times under the control of Rome

displayImages.caption:
Desert citadel
Palmyra has been designated a site of Outstanding Universal Value by Unesco: ‘Its grand, colonnaded street of 1100 metres’ length forms the monumental axis of the city, which together with secondary colonnaded cross streets links the major public monuments including the Temple of Ba’al, Diocletian’s Camp, the Agora, theatre, other temples and urban quarters’ Photograph: Julian Kaesler/Getty Images/Flickr Open
displayImages.altText: Desert Citadel, Palmyra
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Desert citadel
Palmyra has been designated a site of Outstanding Universal Value by Unesco: ‘Its grand, colonnaded street of 1100 metres’ length forms the monumental axis of the city, which together with secondary colonnaded cross streets links the major public monuments including the Temple of Ba’al, Diocletian’s Camp, the Agora, theatre, other temples and urban quarters’

displayImages.caption:
Roman theatre
This unfinished theatre dates back to the 2nd century CE, when Palmyra was once one of the most important cultural centres of the ancient world. In the mid-20th century it was restored and used as a venue for the annual Palmyra festival Photograph: Alamy
displayImages.altText: Roman Theatre, Palmyra
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Roman theatre
This unfinished theatre dates back to the 2nd century CE, when Palmyra was once one of the most important cultural centres of the ancient world. In the mid-20th century it was restored and used as a venue for the annual Palmyra festival

displayImages.caption:
Valley of the Tombs
The Royal Necropolis of Ancient Thebes was located south-west of Palmyra in an area called the Valley of the Tombs. This image shows an underground burial chamber for three wealthy brothers Photograph: Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Valley of Tombs, Palmyra
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Valley of the Tombs
The Royal Necropolis of Ancient Thebes was located south-west of Palmyra in an area called the Valley of the Tombs. This image shows an underground burial chamber for three wealthy brothers

displayImages.caption:
Temple of Ba’al
This great temple of Ba’al was of the most important religious buildings of the 1st century AD. In 1132 the Turkish Burid dynasty turned it into a fortress Photograph: David Forman/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Temple of Ba’al
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Temple of Ba’al
This great temple of Ba’al was of the most important religious buildings of the 1st century AD. In 1132 the Turkish Burid dynasty turned it into a fortress

displayImages.caption:
Tetrapylon on the Cardo Maximus
A striking example of this form of Roman monument, each of the four groups of pillars supports 150,000kg of solid cornice Photograph: Nick Laing/Getty Images/AWL Images RM
displayImages.altText: The Tetrapylon on the Cardo Maximus
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Tetrapylon on the Cardo Maximus
A striking example of this form of Roman monument, each of the four groups of pillars supports 150,000kg of solid cornice
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Nick Laing/Getty Images/AWL Images RM

displayImages.caption:
Ancient burial tower
Tombs were built on high ground on the main road linking Palmyra with Emesa, now known as Homs, and Damascus. This one belonged to the Elhabel family Photograph: Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Ancient burial tower, Valley of the Tombs
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Ancient burial tower
Tombs were built on high ground on the main road linking Palmyra with Emesa, now known as Homs, and Damascus. This one belonged to the Elhabel family

displayImages.caption:
Hadrian’s Gate
Palmyra became a metropolis with ‘free’ status under the Roman emperor Hadrian (117 to 138 CE), who visited the city in 129 CE Photograph: imageBroker/Rex Shutterstock
displayImages.altText: Hadrian’s Gate, Palmyra
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Hadrian’s Gate
Palmyra became a metropolis with ‘free’ status under the Roman emperor Hadrian (117 to 138 CE), who visited the city in 129 CE

displayImages.caption:
Temple of Ba’al, Palmyra
Photograph: Nick Laing/JAI/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Temple of Ba’al, Palmyra
displayImages.cleanCaption: Temple of Ba’al, Palmyra

displayImages.caption:
Stone carvings on the Temple of Ba’al
The art and architecture of Palmyra was a spectacular combination of Greco-Roman techniques, local traditions and Persian influences Photograph: Michele Falzone/JAI/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Stone carvings on the Temple of Ba’al
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Stone carvings on the Temple of Ba’al
The art and architecture of Palmyra was a spectacular combination of Greco-Roman techniques, local traditions and Persian influences

displayImages.caption: Ruins of the Perystil grave temple Photograph: imageBROKER/REX Shutterstock
displayImages.altText: Ruins of the Perystil grave temple, Palmyra
displayImages.cleanCaption: Ruins of the Perystil grave temple

displayImages.caption:
Columns in the inner court of the Temple of Ba’al
Photograph: Richard McManus/Getty Images/Flickr Open
displayImages.altText: Columns in the inner court of the Temple of Ba’al, Palmyra
displayImages.cleanCaption: Columns in the inner court of the Temple of Ba’al

cards.title: Frida Kahlo / Artist at the New York Botanical Garden
cards.rawTitle: Artist at the New York Botanical Garden

item.title: Frida Kahlo at the New York Botanical Garden
item.trailText: In the first show dedicated to Kahlo’s work in New York for 10 years, the Mexican artist’s garden has been recreated in the Bronx, along with an exhibition of her botanically themed works
item.standFirst:
In the first show dedicated to Kahlo’s work in New York for 10 years, the Mexican artist’s garden has been recreated in the Bronx, along with an exhibition of her botanically themed works

The show opens on Saturday and runs until 16 November: details here

item.title: V&A illustration awards: the shortlist
item.trailText: From Life, the Universe and Everything to Treasure Island and the neglected first world war classic In Parenthesis, take a tour around the contenders for the award
item.standFirst: All three artists shortlisted in the book illustration category at this year’s V&A illustration awards have been nominated for books published by the Folio Society. From Life, the Universe and Everything to Treasure Island and the neglected first world war classic In Parenthesis, take a tour around the contenders for the award, which will be awarded on 18 May

displayImages.caption:
Life, the Universe and Everything by Douglas Adams, illustrated by Jonathan Burton
(Folio Society)
‘“We could have a conversation,” said the mattress, “would you like that?”’
From Life, the Universe and Everything by Douglas Adams

• Why we should still read The Hitch-Hiker’s Guide to the Galaxy 30 years on Photograph: Illustration: Jonathan Burton/Folio Society
displayImages.altText: Life, the Universe and Everything by Douglas Adams
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Life, the Universe and Everything by Douglas Adams, illustrated by Jonathan Burton
(Folio Society)
‘“We could have a conversation,” said the mattress, “would you like that?”’
From Life, the Universe and Everything by Douglas Adams

• Why we should still read The Hitch-Hiker’s Guide to the Galaxy 30 years on

displayImages.caption:
‘There was an immensely cold and savage silence. The robots regarded him with hideously dead eyes.’
Photograph: Illustration: Jonathan Burton/Folio Society
displayImages.altText: Life, the Universe and Everything by Douglas Adams
displayImages.cleanCaption: ‘There was an immensely cold and savage silence. The robots regarded him with hideously dead eyes.’

displayImages.caption: ‘He hoped, he hoped, he hoped that his bowling was as bad as he remembered it to be, because that seemed to be the only thing now standing between this moment and universal oblivion.’  Photograph: Illustration: Jonathan Burton/Folio Society
displayImages.altText: Life, the Universe and Everything by Douglas Adams
displayImages.cleanCaption: ‘He hoped, he hoped, he hoped that his bowling was as bad as he remembered it to be, because that seemed to be the only thing now standing between this moment and universal oblivion.’

displayImages.caption:
Treasure Island by Robert Louis Stevenson, illustrated by Sterling Hundley
(Folio Society)
‘He cleared the hilt of his cutlass and loosened the blade in the sheath; and all the time we were waiting there he kept swallowing as if he felt what we used to call a lump in the throat.’

• Andrew Motion on the fatherliness of Long John Sliver Photograph: Illustration: Sterling Hundley/Folio Society
displayImages.altText: Treasure Island by Robert Louis Stevenson illustrated by Sterling Hundley
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Treasure Island by Robert Louis Stevenson, illustrated by Sterling Hundley
(Folio Society)
‘He cleared the hilt of his cutlass and loosened the blade in the sheath; and all the time we were waiting there he kept swallowing as if he felt what we used to call a lump in the throat.’

• Andrew Motion on the fatherliness of Long John Sliver

displayImages.caption:
‘I had hardly moved before the boat, giving up at once her gentle dancing movement, ran straight down a slope of water so steep that it made me giddy.’
Photograph: Illustration: Sterling Hundley/Folio Society
displayImages.altText: Treasure Island by Robert Louis Stevenson illustrated by Sterling Hundley
displayImages.cleanCaption: ‘I had hardly moved before the boat, giving up at once her gentle dancing movement, ran straight down a slope of water so steep that it made me giddy.’

displayImages.caption:
‘One more step, Mr Hands,’ said I, ‘and I’ll blow your brains out!’
Photograph: Illustration: Sterling Hundley/Folio Society
displayImages.altText: Treasure Island by Robert Louis Stevenson illustrated by Sterling Hundley
displayImages.cleanCaption: ‘One more step, Mr Hands,’ said I, ‘and I’ll blow your brains out!’

displayImages.caption:
In Parenthesis by David Jones, illustrated by Ewan Clayton
(Folio Society)
Composed of free verse and prose, In Parenthesis is at once a poem and a novel. Set in the first world war, it is a classic, both of war literature and of modernism, as Chris Power wrote in the Guardian: ‘You wouldn’t think the British Isles had produced enough significant modernist works to ignore one of the best, yet Jones’s work remains woefully neglected. Not that it has lacked advocacy. TS Eliot thought it “a work of genius”’.

Read the full review Photograph: Illustration: Ewan Clayton/Folio Socety
displayImages.altText: In Parenthesis by David Jones illustrated by Ewan Clayton
displayImages.cleanCaption:
In Parenthesis by David Jones, illustrated by Ewan Clayton
(Folio Society)
Composed of free verse and prose, In Parenthesis is at once a poem and a novel. Set in the first world war, it is a classic, both of war literature and of modernism, as Chris Power wrote in the Guardian: ‘You wouldn’t think the British Isles had produced enough significant modernist works to ignore one of the best, yet Jones’s work remains woefully neglected. Not that it has lacked advocacy. TS Eliot thought it “a work of genius”’.

Read the full review

displayImages.altText: In Parenthesis by David Jones illustrated by Ewan Clayton
In Parenthesis by David Jones illustrated by Ewan Clayton

item.title: Fashion for all ages: dungarees
item.trailText: How to work dungarees, whatever your age. Stylist: Melanie Wilkinson. Photography: David Newby
item.standFirst:
If you haven’t worn dungarees since you were playing in the sandpit, now’s the time to reconsider them. Indigo flares, as worn here by Ava, will let you dabble in the 70s trend without looking as if you are wearing noughties boot-cuts, while a clean-lined cotton pair such as Lisskulla’s will look sleek with a crisp shirt. Take a leaf out of Elina’s book and style with flat boots for a tougher take on the trend, or go for a timeless look with Sylviane’s effortless blue denim plus pale grey. Natalie’s distressed pair offers a refreshing break from skinny jeans; team with a boxy jacket for a decidedly grownup look. Melanie Wilkinson

Photographs: David Newby for the Guardian. Styling: Melanie Wilkinson, assisted by Hannah Davidson. Makeup: Lisa Stokes, assisted by Saskia Bannister, using Elemis and Essie Nails. Hair: Ernesto Montenovo at Phamous using Bumble and bumble. Models: Sylviane at Ugly, Lisskulla at Models 1, Natalie at Elite, Ava at Storm, Elina at Profile.
